qas.question: What ancient civilization utilized neoclassicism in city planning?
What basic civil planning system for streets is rooted in neoclassicism?
What are 2 benefits of leveraging neoclassicism for civil planning?
What kind of planning was influenced by classical architecture?
Why did Roman use and open ordered scheme for city planning?
What kind of city planning began with the Romans?
What type of city design frequently used diagonal streets?
What was oriented towards the importance of public buildings?

context: Neoclassicism also influenced <b3_0>city planning<b3_0/>; the <a0_0>ancient Romans<a0_0/> had used a <b5_0>consolidated scheme<b5_0/> for city planning for both <b4_0>defence and civil convenience<b4_0/>, however, the roots of this scheme go back to even older civilizations. At its most basic, the <a1_0>grid system<a1_0/> of streets, a central forum with city services, two main slightly wider boulevards, and the occasional diagonal street were characteristic of the <a2_0>very logical and orderly<a2_0/> <b6_0>Roman design<b6_0/>. <b7_0>Ancient façades<b7_0/> and building layouts were oriented to these city design patterns and they tended to work in proportion with the importance of public buildings.
